text: common mistakes in English lesson seven
topic weather part one watch and listen
right now I'm going to give you a look
into my bedroom closet as you can see
it's a double closet I have one side and
my husband have the other but I have
more clothes than he does so whether he
likes it or not I use his side of the
closet too but actually the only thing
my husband complains about is that I
have some things that are very old and
out of fashion
it's true I have sweatshirts that are at
least ten years old but if you take care
of things they can last a long time
right one problem I have is deciding
what to wear for special events for
example it's hard to decide whether to
wear dress pants like these or skirts
and when you don't know if it will be
warm or cool you ask yourself should I
take a sweater will the sweater go with
my skirt ok so maybe these are doubts
that only women experience but don't men
face fashion dilemmas sometimes I think
they do don't you guys sometimes need a
minute to decide whether you should put
on a tie for a special event and then if
you choose to wear a tie I think you
need another minute or two to choose the
color I think we all want to dress
nicely whether it's to impress others or
simply feel good about the way we look
how well did you understand let's check
and see check one Jennifer said I have
more clothes than my husband does so
whether he likes it or not I use his
side of the closet to question if
Jennifer's husband doesn't like the
situation will Jennifer agree not to use
his side of the closet
know whether or not means he can like
the situation or not like the situation
it doesn't matter to Jennifer she will
continue to use his side of the closet
in any case check to Jennifer said if
you take care of things they can last a
long time
question can if in this statement be
replaced with weather
No weather is often replaced by if in
everyday English but you cannot use
weather in conditional statements note
the statement if you take care of things
they can last a long time the first part
is a condition the second part is a
result when you have this condition then
you get the result this is a conditional
statement you cannot use the word
weather to express the same relationship
so this statement below is incorrect
we cannot say whether you take care of
things they can last a long time it
doesn't make sense you must use if in a
conditional statement check three
Jennifer said it's hard to decide
whether to wear dress pants or a skirt
question can whether in this statement
be replaced with if no weather is often
replaced by if in everyday English but
you cannot use if before an infinitive
such as to wear an infinitive is to plus
the base verb it is correct to say
whether to wear it is incorrect to say
if to wear check for Jennifer said when
you don't know if it will be warm or
cool you ask yourself should I take a
sweater question
can if in this statement be replaced
with weather yes
weather is often replaced by if in
everyday English to express to
alternatives
please note the two alternatives in this
clause when you don't know if it will be
warm or cool the two alternatives are it
may be warm it may be cool
it's also correct to say when you don't
know whether it will be warm or cool now
some grammar sources say that only
weather is the correct word to express
the two alternatives but more and more
in everyday English it's becoming
standard to use if but according to
traditional grammar rules if is only
used to make conditional statements and
we can use weather to express two
possibilities two alternatives in cases
of uncertainty that's why you'll often
see weather following phrases like I
don't know or I wonder they express
uncertainty check five Jennifer said
don't you guys sometimes need a minute
to decide whether you should put on a
tie for a special event question can
whether or not be used in place of
simply weather yes whether or not
expresses two possible alternatives but
or not is usually not necessary to
include note the meaning of this phrase
to decide whether you should put on a
tie means you can choose to put on a tie
you can choose not to put on a tie it's
also correct to say to decide whether or
not you should put on a tie all of these
are correct to decide whether you should
put on a tie to decide whether or not
you should put on a tie to decide
whether you should put on a tie or not
note whether you like it or not is a set
expression you must use or not you
cannot simply say whether you like it
this is part of a larger statement we
can use it in different situations let
me give you two common ones the first is
a situation when you're trying to
express that something is going to
happen and no one can change it hey
whether you like it or not things change
nothing stays the same second situation
is one of defiance meaning you want to
do something you intend to do something
and no one or nothing can stop you no
one or nothing can change your mind
whether you like it or not this is what
I'm going to do it's a statement of
defiance check six Jennifer said I think
we all want to dress nicely whether it's
to impress others or simply feel good
about the way we look question in
Jennifer's opinion how many reasons are
there for dressing nicely - whether or
not implies only two possibilities in
Jennifer's opinion there are only two
possible reasons why we dress nicely one
to impress others two to feel good about
the way we look of course there could be
others but for the sake of this exercise
there are two we've learned quite a lot
about whether let's summarize whether or
not expresses two possible alternatives
whether or not can express that the
result will be the same no matter which
of the two alternatives happens or is
chosen except in the set phrase whether
you like it or not we can omit meaning
leaves out or not the two possible
alternatives are understood by using
only whether if can be used in place of
whether in everyday informal English but
whether cannot be used in condition
statements use if instead if cannot be
used before infinitives or after
prepositions use whether instead end of
part 1 please go on to the next part of
this lesson
